instruction: [INST] Analyze this file to learn MacBook motherboard repair. The 'definitions' section explains key technical terms. The 'threads' section contains real-world repair discussions. Use both sections to understand and learn how to troubleshoot MacBook issues. Posts from username 'larossmann' , 'dukefawks' , and '2informaticos' are posts from trusted experts.[/INST]

definitions.820-00165: What is 820-00165? a LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER.
definitions.BLK_PWM: What is BLK_PWM? BLK_PWM is a typo of BKL_PWM. When you see BLK_PWM assume the poster meant to type BKL_PWM. BKL_PWM sets the brightness of the screen. The system will send a PWM signal to BKL_PWM pin to set brightness. If this is low, backlight voltage will boost higher than PPBUS_G3H input, but not enough to make the screen light properly..
definitions.Q7706: What is Q7706? Q7706 takes PPBUS_G3H's main 12.6v and sends it through to the backlight circuit. If Q9706 is not allowing PPBUS_G3H through, you will get no voltage on the backlight circuit. Q7706 is a P channel MOSFET, meaning power will flow through it when the voltage on the gate is lower than on the source. Look at pin 3. R7788 takes the 12.6v that is on the source and places it right on pin 3. This will set Q7706 to "off", and not allow it to pass power, as the voltage on the source and the gate are identical..
definitions.D7701: What is D7701? diode in the backlight circuit sitting between the BKL_SW pin of the LED driver and backlight output. Very common for via between this and BKL_FB for feedback to blow, causing no boost. Measure continuity between pin 2 of this diode and feedback pin of LED driver if backlight output is PPBUS_G3H with no boost.
definitions.BKL_PWM: What is BKL_PWM? BKL_PWM sets the brightness of the screen. The system will send a PWM signal to BKL_PWM pin to set brightness. If this is low, backlight voltage will boost higher than PPBUS_G3H input, but not enough to make the screen light properly..
definitions.BKL_EN: What is BKL_EN? BKL_EN enables backlight. Anytime you see a signal ending with “_EN” , that means this signal being present/high enables what it is referring to. This signal says “BKL” before “_EN”. “BKL” sounds short for “BACKLIGHT”, so it is safe to assume this signal enables backlight when present. .
definitions.LP8550: What is LP8550? This is an LED driver responsible for creating the backlight on the LCD screen of Macbooks from 2011 through 2015.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00165</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> no backlight
threads.message:
I know no backlight....

I watched a few videos and have learned some but I cannot get this board to give me backlight.

Replaced <TRANSISTOR>Q7706</TRANSISTOR> and <CHIP>U7701</CHIP> and nothing.

<SIGNAL>BLK_PWM</SIGNAL> is 0.509v even after replacing <CHIP>U7701</CHIP>

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00165</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> no backlight
<LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00165</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> no backlight
threads.message:
<SIGNAL>BKL_PWM</SIGNAL> controls <CHIP>U7701</CHIP>, not viceversa!
Post <SIGNAL>BKL_EN</SIGNAL> level too.

We need more info to help.
Post voltage and diode mode to ground on both pins of <DIODE>D7701</DIODE>.
Be aware of XW7720; pictures can be found on the forum.
Do you get image at least (on internal LCD)?
External video OK?

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00165</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> no backlight
<LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00165</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> no backlight
threads.message:
<SIGNAL>BKL_EN</SIGNAL> 2.8v
<DIODE>D7701</DIODE> 8.59v both legs
<DIODE>D7701</DIODE> 586 on the left and 408 on the right
XW7720 looks almost gone, a little better than this one [url]https://drive.google.com/file/d/18UR9ufMnaWRTbwZwNjTTxmIcHGCNpSBl/view[/url] but damaged, so I ran a jumper from what was left of that pad to <DIODE>D7701</DIODE> and also checked continuity from there to pin 5 of <CHIP>U7701</CHIP>, but still nothing 
Yes I see the folder question mark when I light the LCD from the back, did not check external video, but I assume is fine.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00165</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> no backlight
threads.message: Not sure if you get a notification when I reply as a comment, let me know.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00165</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> no backlight
threads.message: No we do not. Please only reply. Let me be more clear. Post voltage on  <CAPACITOR>C7797</CAPACITOR>. If 8.59 volts, then something wrong with feedback/the LED driver.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00165</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> no backlight
threads.message:
If you've changed <CHIP>U7701</CHIP>, post now diode mode (red probe at ground) on all return resistors.

Do PRAM reset few times.
If <SIGNAL>BKL_PWM</SIGNAL> still low, then remove <RESISTOR>R7704</RESISTOR> and run a wire from <RESISTOR>R7715</RESISTOR> to <CAPACITOR>C7704</CAPACITOR>.
Check if backlight comes on.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00165</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> no backlight
threads.message:
[USER="1153"]JohnB8812[/USER] <CAPACITOR>C7797</CAPACITOR> indeed is 8.56v 

[USER="682"]2informaticos[/USER] all return resistors measure 0.630
<RESISTOR>R7704</RESISTOR> is 0.504v
I ran a wire from <RESISTOR>R7715</RESISTOR> to <CAPACITOR>C7704</CAPACITOR> after removing <RESISTOR>R7704</RESISTOR> and no backlight either, folder with question mark flashes when I use a flash-light but no backlight yet.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00165</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> no backlight
threads.message: Did you try known good compatible LCD assembly?

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00165</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> no backlight
threads.message:
Yes, good know compatible LCD.

I put a new <CHIP>LP8550</CHIP> and all is working again, thanks [USER="682"]2informaticos[/USER]  and [USER="1153"]JohnB8812[/USER] for all the help.
